concern: I am absolutely disgusted at how abusive my graduate professors have been, at least in comparison to my undergraduate professors. This seems to be way more common for graduate professors. Itâ€™s just so upsetting and hard to deal with.

dialogue_total.statement: Hello! I'm glad you're here today. Is there anything on your mind that you'd like to discuss or explore together?
Hey, thanks. Yeah, I've just been really stressed about how my grad professors treat us. It's so different from undergrad and feels overwhelming.
therapist: It sounds like the transition from undergrad to grad school is bringing a lot of stress and overwhelm for you. What has been the hardest part about how your professors are treating you?

client: I think it's the way they talk to us, like they expect us to already know everything, and there's no patience or understanding. It makes asking questions feel really intimidating, unlike in undergrad where professors were more approachable.

therapist: You feel intimidated because the professors' expectations make it seem like you should already know everything, which is quite different from the supportive environment you experienced during your undergrad. What impact has this had on your learning experience so far?
client: It's making it really hard to stay motivated and actually engage with the material. I feel anxious a lot of the time, and it's affecting how I absorb and retain the information.

It sounds like this experience is affecting both your motivation and your ability to engage with the material. That's a lot to carry. On a scale from 0 to 10, how confident do you feel about finding a way to navigate this challenge?
I'd say maybe a 3 or 4? I mean, I want to get through this and find a way to cope, but it just feels really daunting right now.

It seems like you're feeling quite overwhelmed right now, but it's great to hear that you still have a desire to find a way to cope. What might help in moving that confidence level up even just a small bit?

Honestly, maybe finding some strategies to communicate better with them or figuring out how to manage my stress when things get tough. It might also help if I could connect with other students who feel the same way, just to know I'm not alone in this.

It sounds like you're considering some promising approaches. Connecting with others who share similar experiences and finding strategies to improve communication might really help in managing the stress. What would taking that first step toward one of these ideas look like for you?

I guess I could start by reaching out to some classmates and see how they're feeling about everything. Maybe setting up a study group or something where we can share our experiences and support each other might be a good start.
It seems like you're envisioning a supportive community with your classmates, which could really make a difference. How does this idea of connecting with them align with your values and goals?
I think it fits well because I really value support and connection with others. Plus, working together could help us all get through this without feeling so isolated and stressed out.

Building connections and supporting each other truly reflects your values, and it's inspiring to see how you're aligning these efforts with your goals. How do you feel about the potential impact this community might have on your stress levels and overall college experience?
I feel like having that kind of support could make things a lot more manageable. Just knowing I'm not the only one struggling might take a huge load off and make the whole experience more bearable.

It sounds like connecting with your classmates could really reduce stress and enhance your college experience. Based on this, possible steps might include organizing a group chat or planning a meet-up. What would be a realistic first step for you to initiate this supportive community?
I think starting with a group chat could be a good first step. It's easy to set up and doesn't require too much coordination, so we can just see who's interested and take it from there.
Creating a group chat sounds like a practical and manageable first step. What specific platform might you use for this group chat, and how do you plan to invite your classmates to join?
Iâ€™m thinking of using something like WhatsApp or Discord since most people already use those. I'll probably just mention it in class or send out an email to see whoâ€™s interested in joining.

That sounds like a solid plan! Itâ€™s great to see you taking proactive steps towards building a supportive network. Starting with a group chat on WhatsApp or Discord seems like a practical choice, and mentioning it in class or via email is an excellent way to invite your classmates. Remember, youâ€™re not alone in this, and by reaching out, youâ€™re creating an opportunity for others to feel connected too. Take it one step at a time and see how it evolves. Youâ€™re building something meaningful, and thatâ€™s truly admirable. If you need any support or would like to share your progress, feel free to reach out anytime. You're doing amazing, and Iâ€™m here to support you on this journey.
Thanks, I appreciate that. I'll try to take it slow and see how it goes. It's a bit nerve-wracking, but I'm hopeful it'll be worth it.
